particulars: from 04-08 till 11-08 in the Mosselbaai; from 13-09 till 07-10 in the Ampalazabaai; from 09-10 till 13-12 in S. Augustins Bay, where before departure 127 of the 249 men were still alive; 11-01 till 21-01 at Ste. Marie I.; from 23-01 till 12-02 in the Bay of Antongil. The AMSTERDAM was set on fire near Bawean, 11-01-1597.
HOLLANDIA on 26-10-1595; he was succeeded by Hendrik Jansz.
Jan Dignumsz. died on 29-05-1595 and Mau was his successor.
Jan Jansz. died on 25-12-1596 and Hendrik Jansz. was his successor.

01-04 till 17-04 at Torbay; from 11-05 till 19-05 at S. Nicolas; from 21-06 till 05-09 before Fernando de Noronha; from 17-11 till 18-11 in St. Helena Bay; from 21-11 till 07-12 in the Saldanha Bay; from 13-02 till 24-03 in S. Augustins Bay; from 10-04 till 27-04 at Mayotte; from 29-04 till 08-05 at Anjouan.

Fleet (0010-0017) of the Oude Oost-Indische Compagnie under command of admiral Jakob Kornelisz. van Neck aboard the MAURITIUS and vice-admiral Wybrand van Warwijck aboard the AMSTERDAM. On 08-08 1598 the fleet was split up in 2 parts, 1 part - the MAURITIUS, the HOLLANDIA and the OVERIJSSEL - under command of Van Neck took on provisions from 07-09 till 11-09 at Ste. Marie I. and from 12-09 till 16-09 in the Bay of Antongil. Only 2 men died. The other half under command of Van Warwijck took on provisions from 19-09 till 02-10 on an island, they named it Mauritius.
Also mentioned as HOLLANDSE LEEUW.
The former DUIFJE of the Eerste Schipvaart.

Fleet (0018-0023) equipped by the Rotterdamse or Magelhaanse Compagnie under command of admiraal Jacques de Mahu and vice-admiraal Simon de Cordes; from 02-04 till 29-09 at the Cape Verde I.; from 16-12- till 02-01 at Annabon; April 7th the fleet entered Strait of Magellan; the fleet wintered in the Fortesene Bay till 23-08 and from 24-08 till 28-08 in Ridres Bay; during this winter 120 men died. September 3rd the fleet entered the Pacific, where it was scattered by heavy storms. Mahu died 23-09-1598, De Cordes succeeded. In Valparaiso the Spaniards laid an embargo on the BLIJDE BOODSCHAP, 17-11-1599; Dirk Gerritsz. Pomp, who succeeded Sebald de Weert as master on 24-09-1598, and his crew (18 men) were taken prisoner.

The GELOOF met the fleet of Van Noort and joined in; tried for 9 months to sail through the Strait but failed to do so; returned with 36 men under Sebald de Weert, who succeeded Van Beuningen, to Holland and arrived in Goeree 13-07-1600.
De Cordes, on board of the HOOP, was killed by natives on La Mocha I., 11-11-1599 and succeeded by Hudcupee; the HOOP sailed via Hawaii and was lost with all hands, 24-09-1600.

Van Beuningen, vice-admiraal since 24-09-1598, aboard the LIEFDE was killed in S. Maria with 22 men and succeeded by Kwakernaak; the LIEFDE sailed via Hawaii and arrived in Japan 19-04-1600 with only 24/25 men. The Japanese confiscated the ship, but released the crew; later the ship was lost in Japanese waters.
The POSTILJON was taken with the fleet in 4 parts and put together in Strait of Magellan, but lost with all hands in the Pacific.

The TROUW, under command of Balthasar de Cordes, who succeeded Jurriaan van Bokholt after his death 28-04-1599, arrived in Tidore, where the Portuguese laid an embargo on the ship and killed almost the whole crew.

Fleet (0024-0027) under command of admiraal Olivier van Noort aboard the MAURITIUS and vice-admiraal Jakob Klaasz. van Ilpendam aboard the HENDRIK FREDERIK. Total of those on board 248. The MAURITIUS and the EENDRACHT were equipped by a Rotterdam company, the HENDRIK FREDERIK and the HOOP by an Amsterdam company. From 11-12 till 17-12 at Principe I. From 02-06 till 21-06 at S. Clara I., where the EENDRACHT was deserted and set on fire, because of unseaworthiness; from 20-09 till 29-10 at Port Desire; October 9th. the HOOP was renamed EENDRACHT; from 04-11 till 29-02 in Strait of Magellan, where they meet the GELOOF of the fleet of Mahu; January 26th Van Ilpendam was left behind on an island because of insubordination, De Lint became his successor as vice-admiraal from 15-10 till 20-11 at the Philippines and December 9th. before Manila, where the EENDRACHT was captured by the Spaniards December 14th. The MAURITIUS proceeded alone to Borneo December 26th; the HENDRIK FREDERIK ran ashore near Ternate, February 1601 and was sold to the sultan of Ternate. Huidekoper, captain of the HOOP died October 7th and was succeeded by Pieter de Lint who on his turn was succeeded by Lambert Biesman January 28th, 1600, after his appointment as vice-admiraal in stead of Van Ilpendam.
Ran ashore at Ternate.

till 16-05 at Maio I.; from 02-07 till 17-07 before Corsico; from 27-10 till 10-11 Sonnebaai (Madagascar) and from 17-11 till 21-12 in the Bay of Antongil.
Squadron (0031-0034) of the fleet of Van Neck which sailed later under command of vice-admiraal Jakob Willekens aboard the MAURITIUS.
Fleet (0035-0038) under command of admiraal Pieter Both aboard the NEDERLAND and vice-admiraal Paulus van Caerden aboard the VERENIGDE LANDEN, equipped by the Nieuwe Brabantsche Compagnie.

Fleet (0039-0040) under command of admiraal Guilleaume Seneschel aboard the ZWARTE AREND, equipped by the Nieuwe Brabantsche Compagnie. From 01-07 till 06-07 at the Downs; from 12-07 till 14-07 at Portland; from 29-09 till 31-09 at Annabon.

Fleet (0041-0046) under command of Van Neck aboard the AM-STERDAM and Foreest aboard the DORDRECHT, equipped by the Oude Oostindische Compagnie. From 01-10 till 10-10 at Annabon whereafter the fleet was divided into 2 squadrons: 1 squadron under command of Van Neck, consisted of the AMSTERDAM, the GOUDA, the DELFT and the other under command of Foreest, consisted of the LEIDEN, the DOR-DRECHT and the HAARLEM.
Left behind at Patani in September 1603 as unseaworthy.
number of deaths 5.
The master died at Patani in 1602.
Bouwer, equipped by the Oude Oostindische Compagnie. From 27-09 till 20-10 at Mauritius.

Fleet (0056-0063) under command of admiraal Jakob van Heemskerk aboard the AMSTERDAM, equipped by the Eerste Verenigde Compagnie op Oost-Indie. From 24-06 till 01-07 at Fernando Noronha; from 10-11 till 08-12 at Mayotte.

Compagnie de Moucheron. T otal number of those on board 225. The SCHAAP took on provisions from 21-02 till 04-04 at the Comoro and May 31th at Ceylon. The RAM with vice-admiraal Guyon Le Fort on board via the Bay of Augustin and Ceylon.
With the death of Le Fort (26-06) the RAM was sold to the V.O.C. and put under the command of Sebald de Weert (see 0067-69).
fleet of Van Warwyck. The three ships of Zeeland preceded the rest of the fleet. Took on provisions in the Bay of Antongil.

The equipment (0070-0081) of the `Fourteen ships' (without the jacht PAPEGAAITJE) under admiraal Wybrand van Warwyck on the MAURITIUS.From June 24th till July 10th the fleet lay off Plymouth; from October 11th till 21th off Annabon; and was on December 12th near the Cape. December 14th the HOLLAND, the HOLLANDSE TUIN and the STER left the main fleet, and set sail for Atjeh, the remainder sailed for Bantam.

fleet was before Johore where it started operations against the Portuguese. The ERASMUS, the PRO-VINCIEN and probably the EENDRACHT departed not before 30-05 from the Maas. The first 2 ships joined Matelieff on 14-07-1607 off Malacca, the EENDRACHT was sent for Mauritius to collect ebony. In August 1610 this ship was destroyed by fire on the coast of Coromandel. The ship probably never formed part of the fleet of Matelieff. The GROTE ZON and the KLEINE ZON stayed in the Indies and were broken up at Banda.

illemsz. Verhoeff aboard the GEUNIEERDE PROVINCIEN and vice-adm. Frans Hendriksz. Wittert aboard the MIDDELBURG. The 3 Zeeland ships and the mainfleet met at Maio I. Destined to explore the North-East passage to the Indies; discovered Hudson Bay and returned 07-12 in Dartmouth. Further information see I'Honore Naber.
left Lissabon 05-02-1610, rounded the Cape 04-05, took on provisions from 25-06 till 06-07 at Madagascar. It stayed in the Indies.

Lost sight of the fleet; from 30-07 till 02-08 at the Bay of Antipara; 02-08 in the St. Lucia Bay, where it took over the remaining cargo of the MAURITIUS (5077); 21-08 departure from Madagascar via the Bay of Antongil; from 27-10 till 08-12 at Mauritius.
Lost sight of the fleet; from 24-07 till 03-08 in the `Verhagensbaai'; from 29-08 till 27-09 at Mayotte.

Fleet (0143-0144) under the command of Hendrik Brouwer aboard the RODE LEEUW MET PIJLEN sailed the southern passage for the first time (latitude ca. 36' south), which was made obligatory in 1616. The GOUDA was captured by the Spaniards near Tidore, 04-05-1612.

Fleet (0169-0170) under the command of Jasper van Surk aboard the MIDDELBURG. May 4th at Maio I.; August 10th the ZEELANDIA disappeared from sight and the MIDDELBURG reprovisioned in St. Lucia Bay. Later the MIDDELBURG was lost near Surat, 19-07-1617.

Gerard Reynst and admiraal Steven van der Hagen aboard the WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM. From 29-09 till 05-10 at S. Vincente; January \n10th. at Cape Lopez; from 21-02 till 02-03 at Annabon; May 31th. somewhere off the Cape; from 13-06 till 21-07 at the Comoro Islands.
According to Coolhaas the ship arrived at Bantam 16-01-1615. The ship stayed in the Indies and ran aground in the river Andragiri 19-09-1615.
Reprovisioned at the Cape and sailed, before arriving at Bantam, by mistake to Bali.

Fleet (0177-0182) under command of Adriaan Woutersz. Stoop (+ 26-11-1615) aboard the VLISSINGEN. The VLISSINGEN had a difficult voyage; 19-12 rounding the Cape the ship sailed north too early; 18-11-1615 (!) it encountered the WALCHE-REN, the ENGEL and the AMSTERDAM.

The SARA JACOBA called at Saldanha Bay (25-06 till 01-08-1742) where 9 seafarers and 4 soldiers died. The six passengers who embarked at the Cape included ex-Governor-General Adriaan Valkenier, arrested at the Cape after his return from Batavia in January 1742 (see also 7130); he was accused by the future Governor-General Van Imhoff of being reponsible for the notorious 'Chinese murders' in Batavia in 1740.

The ANNA called at Madeira (12 till 14-11-1742) and at S. Tiago (25/6-11-1742). During the voyage, probably at the Cape, one seafarer was taken over by the EENDRACHT (3254); five soldiers became seafarers.

31-12-1743) where 8 seafarers deserted. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
At the Cape 6 soldiers probably became seafarers.
During the voyage Jan Bop succeeded Jan Raay as master, one source mentions Gerrit Bot. From 26-12-1743 till 06-02-1744 the ship was at Morlaix.
One week after its departure from Texel the ship returned (04-12-1743); on 27-12 it sailed out again. The HUTS TE MAR-QUETTE was sold at Batavia on 10-11-1747.

On its way to the Cape the ship called at Duins (08-till 13-12-1743) where 2 seafarers deserted, at Dassen Island (17-02 till 06-03-1744), and at Saldanha Bay. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
(17-12-1743 till 06-01-1744) where 11 seafarers and 4 soldiers were pressed by the English. During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
At the Cape one stowaway, not registered in the columns, disembarked; one soldier became third meester (counted as seafarer).
From 02 till 04-02-1744 the DISHOEK called at S. Tiago where one seafarer died, another seafarer and one soldier deserted.
embarked, two of them died on the way to Batavia.
S. Tiago where two seafarers died and six soldiers deserted. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 03-06-1749.
09-01-1744 Was the final date of departure of the SIJBEKAR-SPEL; on 01-01-1744 the ship set out for the first time. but four days later it returned to Texel.

From 07 till 18-02-1744 the RUITER called at S. Tiago where one seafarer and five soldiers died; the crew was enlarged by one seafarer, taken over from the OUWERKERK (see 3293), and one soldier. At the Cape ten seafarers deserted. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 03-06-1749.
The KNAPENHOF called at Duins (16-01 till 03-02-1744). It did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer. The seven passengers were criminals. The NIEUW VIJVERVREUGD exploded in 1746 on the roads of Batavia.
The LEEUWERIK called at S. Tiago (10 till 17-07-1744). In 1748 the ship was wrecked near Macassar.
Tiago. One of the soldiers became cook's wain. The 2 seafarers who embarked at the Cape included a master, Kornelis Booys.
From 04 till 15-10-1744 the DIEMERMEER was at S. Tiago.
The KETEL called at Portsmouth from 06-08 till 09-12-1744. See also 3313. According to a Resolution of Gouverneur-Generaal en Raden the ship was sold to Spanish merchants at Manila in 1748.
The VOORZICHTIGHEID did not call at the Cape but at Saldanha Bay.

One day after its departure the ship returned to Goeree (07-11-1744); it finally set out on 08-12-1744. From 29-12-1744 till 26-01-1745 the ship called at Duins. The HUIS TE PERSIJN did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay (25-05 till 11-06-1745). During the voyage 4 soldiers became seafarers.
after its departure the ship returned to Texel (10-11-1744); it finally sailed out on 09-12. The eight passengers included one female slave. The HOF VAN DELFT was sold in the Indies on 17-02-1750.
Four days after its departure the DIEMEN returned to Texel (10-11-1744); it finally set out on 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.
7208). Nanning Broeder died, his successor is unknown.
to Texel on 10-11 ; it finally departed on 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 200,000 in cash.
The ZUIDERBURG returned to Texel on 10-11, its final date of departure was 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.

Some of the 29 persons who disembarked at the Cape went to the KETEL (see 3304); the 16 embarking persons partially came from the KETEL and the LEIDEN (see 3321). One soldier became cook's wain. The BROUWER replaced the ABBEKERK, wrecked on a return voyage in 1742 (see 7139).
At the Cape one seafarer turned out to be a woman, she continued the voyage as passenger. One soldier became cook's wain. The DOMBURG carried f 250,000 in cash.
the ship was at S. Tiago. One of the craftsmen became bottler's mate. The SPANDERSWOUD carried f 100,000 in cash.
The HUIS TE SPIJK was laid up and sold at Batavia on 18-07-1752.

From 02 till 13-03-1745 the SCHELLAG was at S. Tiago: at Porto Prayo the crew was enlarged with 16 seafarers and 27 soldiers. These 43 persons came from the SCHONAUWEN (see 3320). The ship carried f 100,000 in cash. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

-01-1745 Was the final date of departure of the VREELAND: on 06-12-1744 the ship sailed out for the first time, it returned to Texel the same day however. The ship called at Torbay (24 till 29-01-1745) and at Plymouth (05 till 26-02-1745). It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay: the two passengers who embarked there included one slave. The VREELAND was laid up at Batavia on 10-11-1750.
SCHELLAG (see 3318). The SCHONAUWEN did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship was sold at Batavia on 29-01-1754.
At the Cape one seafarer was taken over by the BROUWER (see 3313), another disembarked.
The HARTENLUST did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.

before the IDA reached the Cape 20 seaferers and 11 soldiers were taken over from the DUINENBURG (see 3331). The ship was laid up in the Indies on 11-05-1751. Klaas van den Hoed and Jakob van der Meer are also mentioned in sources as master of the IDA.
From 21-05 till 09-06-1745 the NIEUWSTAD called at S. Tiago where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. At the Cape one seafarer turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as a passenger.
soldiers became seafarers. The GOID-SCHALXOORD was laid up at Batavia in 1750.
RIJNHUIZEN was laid up at Batavia on 31-12-1751.
The SPION called at S. Tiago (25 till 30-07-1745), and at the island Annabon (19 till 22-09); from 29 till 31-10 the ship was off Angola.
at Saldanha Bay. See also the IDA (3325).
The HERSTELDER called at Saldanha Bay from 06 till 25-11-1745.
29-09-1745): at Porto Prayo 3 seafarers and 3 soldiers deserted. The ship also called at Robben Island (29 till 31-12-1745).
Tiago where one seafarer and four soldiers deserted.

14 till 22-09 the WESTHOVEN was at Portsmouth where 6 seafarers and 4 soldiers were pressed by the English. The ship also called at Dassen Island from 06 till 18-01-1746. The passenger who embarked at the Cape was a stowaway, found on the REIGERSDAAL (see 7230).
from Batavia to Banda. Francois Pennink and Reinier van der Luchten also are mentioned in sources as master of the NIEUWERKERK.
The FORTUIN carried f 150,000 in cash.
The LEKKERLAND carried f 250,000 in cash.
During the voyage, probably in November, 43 soldiers were taken over from the WILDRIJK (see 3343) and other ships. The SCHEIJBEEK carried f 200,000 in cash.
November, many soldiers, presumably about 40, were taken over by the SCHEIJBEEK (see 3342). The WILDRIJK carried f 145,000 in cash.
The SARA JACOBA was laid up and sold at Batavia on 02-02-1753.
The WAAKZAAAMHEID called at S. Tiago from 21 tilt 26-01-1746.

15-12-1745 Was the final date of departure of the EINDHOEF; on 24-11-1745 the ship set out for the first time but four days later it returned: 20 soldiers disembarked and 30 seafarers were taken over from the HUIS TE RENSBURG (see 3353); the original crew consequently was altered into 83 seafarers and 21 soldiers.
turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as a passenger.

Five days after its departure the ship returned to Texel (20-02-1746); it finally set out on 10-03-1746. From 05 till 09-04-1746 the GETROUWIGHEID called at S. Tiago. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
Smalle Baei'.

23-03-1746 Was the final date of departure of the SPAREN-RIJK; on 15-02-1746 the ship sailed out for the first time, but five days later it returned. The SPARENRIJK did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
False Bay.

09-04-1746 Was the final date of departure of the HUIS TE RENSBURG; on 24-11-1745 it set out for the first time, but on 27-01-1746 it returned. Thirty seafarers had been taken over by the EINDHOEF (see 3346); the first column indicates the final composition of the crew. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The RUST EN W ERK did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
Pieter Schildman was master and that he died before reaching the Cape. From 08 till 15-05-1746 the STANDVASTIGHEID was at Porto Prayo (S. Tiago). The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The four passengers included one slave. The TOLSDUIN called at S. Tiago (03 till 06-05-1746) and at False Bay.
The SLOT VAN KAPELLE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship carried f 225,000 in cash.
was at Duins.
23-05-1746 the BATAVIER was at Duins.

The MAARSSEVEEN called at Duins (09 till 23-05-1746) and at S. Tiago (10-06 till 12-07-1746). where the crew was enlarged by 9 French seafarers. In 1748 the ship exploded on a voyage from Banda to Batavia.
See also 3364. In 1751 the WESTKAPELLE was laid up at Bengal.
From 07 till 22-07-1746 the BOSBEEK called at S. Tiago, where four soldiers `disembarked' (they probably died); the crew was enlarged by five French seafarers.
See also 3364.
21-08-1746). Some of the 17 persons who disembarked at the Cape were taken over by the WESTKA-PELLE (3361) and the OUWERKERK (3363).
From 28-06 till 06-07-1746 the ship was at Duins.
The SIJBEKARSPEL called at S. Tiago from 27-08 till 03-09-1746 where 3 French seafarers embarked. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.
The KRABBENDUKE called at Portsmouth from 05 till 21-08-1746.
The OVERNES called at Portsmouth (05-08 till 21-08-1746 (?)) and at S. Tiago (08 till 14-09-1746).
From 13 till 26-10-1746 the GUSTAAF WILLEM called at S. Tiago. After the departure from the Cape two stowaways were found.
The BEUKESTIJN carried_f 150,000 in cash. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.
During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers. The HAAR-LEM carried _/'300,000 in cash.
3373/7283 Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its four preceding voyages was called KERKWIJK (3223/7216). The HUTS TE RENSBURG carried f 200,000 in cash.
From 20 till 26-02-1747 the HUIS TE MANPAD called at Robben Island. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.
The OOSTKAPELLE called Robben Island from 03 till 13-02-1747.
From 03 till 13-02-1747 the NIEUW WALCHEREN called at Robben Island. The ship was wrecked on the roads of Surat on 24-05-1748.
Some of the 16 persons who disembarked at the Cape were taken over by the LEIDEN (see 3382).
out to be a woman, she continued the voyage as a passenger.
The four passengers included two female slaves. The DIEMEN carried f 130,000 in cash.
Sea'. From 30-12-1746 till 05-01-1747 the LEIDEN was at S. Tiago. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.

Martin den Breems \ndied. at the Cape he was succeeded by Pieter\nPietersz. The 5 passengers included one slave. The ZUIDER-BURG called at S. Tiago (31-12-1746 till 09-01-1747) and at Robben Island (17 till 19-03-1747). The ship carried f 150,000 in cash
The OUD BERKENRODE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. On 04-12-1747 the ship was wrecked 'in the Bight of Anjer'; most of the cargo and crew was saved.
/- Is the seventh voyage of this ship, which during its first four voyages was called WAPEN VAN HOORN. The ship was wrecked on a return voyage from Surat to Batavia on 08-06-1751.
The WELTEVREDEN did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The VLISSINGEN was lost between patria and the Cape.
The DOMBURG did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
the Cape but at False Bay.
did not call at the Cape but at False Bay and Simon's Bay (17-06 till 04-07-1747). The ship was sold at Batavia on 19-03-1748.
but at False Bay.
The HUIS TER DUINE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
In 1748 the HUIS TE PERSIJN was wrecked on a return voyage from Japan.
From 28-06 till 03-07-1747 the SCHAKENBOS was at S. Tiago.
On 25-10-1747 the REIGERSDAAL was wrecked off the Cape. Wreck discovered.
The KLEVERSKERKE called at S. Tiago, where one seafarer disembarked, another one and one soldier deserted.
From 17-11 till 07-12-1747 the BROUWER called at Saldanha Bay.
From 05 till 13-09-1747 the ZAAMSLAG was at `Goeree near Cape Verde'.
From 27-09 till 01-10-1747 the IMMAGONDA called at S. Tiago where 2 seafarers and 2 soldiers deserted.

The SCHELLAG called at S. Tiago from 22-09 till 01-10-1747 where one sailmaker was taken over by the IMMAGONDA (see 3404), another seafarer and 16 soldiers deserted. In 1748, during a return voyage from Japan, the ship was captured by the French.
From 25-12-1747 till 05-01-1748 the AMSTELVEEN called at S. Tiago. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.
deserted. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.
carried f 100,000 in cash. The EINDHOEF was laid up and sold at Batavia on 31-12-1755.
and one seafarer embarked. The ship carried f 100.000 in cash.
OSDORP called at S. Tiago from 23-12-1747 till 03-01-1748 where 5 seafarers and 13 soldiers died or deserted. The ship carried f 100,000 in cash.
From 23 till 28-12-1747 the VOSMAAR called at S. Tiago where one seafarer died and two soldiers embarked.
The BEVALLIGHEID called at Portsmouth (08 till 15-01-1748) where 11 seafarers and 4 soldiers deserted or were pressed by the English.
The SLOTEN carried f 150,000 in cash.
The SLOTERDIJK carried f 150,000 in cash.
130,000 in cash.
On the way four seafarers and nine soldiers deserted.
to Texel on 10-05. The two passengers were stowaways found after the departure from the Cape; one of them was the wife of a sergeant.
out on 06-05-1748; four days later it returned to Texel after having run aground 'at the Haaks'. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 01-05-1752.
One source mentions Thomas Hardy as master. The ZEELANDIA was wrecked in the Indies.
The DISHOEK was laid up in the Indies on 31-12-1756.
As the BREDENHOF and the LIS (see 3419 and 3420) the HERCULES initially set out on 06-05-1748; four days later the ship returned to Texel after having run aground 'at the Haaks'.

/- Is the sixth voyage of this ship, which during its first four voyages was called KERKWIJK (3223/7216) and during its fifth voyage HUIS TE RENSBURG (3373/7283). The ship was sold at Batavia on 29-01-1754.
The GELDERMALSEN called at S. Tiago from 15 till 30-09-1748.
From 08 till 18-12-1748 the WESTHOVEN was at Robben Island. The ship was sold at Malacca.
The PRINSES VAN ORANJE was bought in England where it had been built by Wells and Stanton, a shipyard on the Thames; the ship arrived at Texel in January 1748.
The OUDKARSPEL called at Duins from 10 till 15-11-1748.

was called DUINENBURG (3331/7258). 04-11-1748 Was the final date of departure of the HUIS TE RENS-BURG; the ship initially sailed out on 06-05-1748, but it returned four days later after having run aground `at the Haaks' (at that moment its name still was DUINENBURG). On 15-11-1748 the ship was at Duins.
15-11-1748. For seven years the ship was on service at the Cape: in 1756 it was wrecked on a voyage from the Cape to False Bay.

Initially the POLANEN departed on 15-11, but four days later it returned to Texel. The ship called at Duins twice: 11-12-1748 till 09-01-1749 and 22-01 till 22-02-1749. Adriaan Waag did not survive the voyage, Hilde Hendriksz. Hoek succeeded him as master. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

of its course by a heavy storm, the ship stranded near Portsmouth; before it got afloat 137 seafarers, 83 soldiers and 12 craftsmen deserted. From 17-02, the day the ship got afloat, till 10-05-1749 the OVER-SCHIE remained at Portsmouth; the diminished crew was enlarged by 113 seafarers, 74 soldiers, 3 craftsmen and 12 passengers, all sent from Delft. During the voyage at least 5 soldiers probably became seafarers.

stranded near Portsmouth; after getting afloat it sailed to Spithead. The PASGELD remained there till 09-02 and, after a vain attempt to depart, from 12-02 till 10-04-1749. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

15-11-1748 (return to Texel: 19-11) and 21-11 (return: 06-12). On 26-01-1749 the ship ran ashore between Hastings and Beachy Head. The value of silver in coins and bars was f 300,104; most of it was recovered within a few days after the loss.
The ELSWOUD called at Duins. 24-01 till 22-02-1749. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay, 02-06 till 03-07-1749 During the voyage 2 soldiers probably became seafarers.
From 20-01 till 22-02-1749 the HAARLEM called at Duins.
The HARTEKAMP did not call at the Cape but at False Bay; the 8 seafarers who disembarked there included one drummer, 2 seafarers went over to the HUIS TE MANPAD (see 3441).
From 23-01 till 22-02 the HUIS TE MANPAD was at Duins. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay; the 2 seafarers who embarked there came from the HARTEKAMP (see 3440).
The SPARENRIJK called at Spithead twice: 20-01 till 09-02 and 12 till 22-02-1749. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay, 16-06 till 08-07-1749.
From 23-01 till 22-02-1749 the HOF D'UNO was at Duins. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay, 12-07 till 25-08-1749.
From 13 till 22-02 the DIEMEN was at Duins. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay from 08-06 till 03-07-1749.
The SPANDERSWOUD called at Duins, 13 till 22-02-1749. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay from 02-06 till 03-07-1749.
26-07-1749. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
the BOSBEEK was at S. Tiago. It did not call at the Cape but at Saldanha Bay, 26-07 till 18-09-1749. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia, 05-01-1754.

The SCHEIJBEEK made two earlier attempts to depart: 21-11-1748 and 10-01-1749 (return to Rammekens: 31-01). From 18-04 till 01-05-1749 the ship was at S. Tiago: 9 soldiers deserted. The SCHEIJBEEK was laid up in India, 09-08-1755.
The VREDE made one earlier attempt to depart: 10-01; three weeks later it returned to Rammekens (31-01-1749). From 18-04 till 01-05-1749 the ship called at S. Tiago.
The GUSTAAF WILLEM called at S. Tiago. 23-04 till 01-05-1749. The two passengers were slaves.
From 07 till 15-05-1749 the WILDRIJK called at S. Tiago. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay from 20-08 till 19-09-1749.
The VOORZICHTIGHEID called at Portsmouth from 24-04 till 07-05-1749.
Duins (24-04 till 07-05-1749) and at S. Tiago (02 till 07-06-1749).
From 03 till 07-06-1749 the PRINSES CAROLINA called at S. Tiago.
called at S. Tiago from 05 till 11-06-1749.
KRABBENDIJKE called at S. Tiago. The ship replaced the DIEMERMEER, wrecked in 1747 (see 7257).
On its way to the Cape the WAPEN VAN HOORN called at Duins (24-06 till 08-07-1749) and at S. Tiago (17 till 24-08-1749).
The DEUNISVELD called at S. Tiago from 25-08 till 09-09-1749.
From 11 till 17-07-1749 the HUIS TER DUINE was at S. Tiago.

master: Pieter de Waayer de la Rue

particulars: probably became soldiers.
The HUIS TE RENSBURG called at Duins (15 till 20-07-1749) and at Portsmouth (02 till 25-08-1749). The ship was sold in the Indies, 29-06-1753.
OVERNES called at Duins (15 till 20-07-1749) and at S. Tiago (01-09 till 13-09-1749).
The ZUIDERBURG called at Duins (15 till 20-07-1749) and at S. Tiago (01 till 13-09-1749). During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
From 10 till 17-10-1749 the ANNA was at Porto Prayo on S. Tiago. The ship was sold at Batavia, 30-12-1758.
The NIEUWVIJVERVREUGD called at S. Tiago from 10 till 18-10-1749.

From 01 till 08-11-1749 the SPREEUW called at S. Tiago. The ship was destined to remain on service between Batavia and the Cape.
The TOLSDUIN was laid up at the Cape, 15-06-1752.
The GERECHTIGHEID called at Duins from 15 till 21-10-1749.
The ROTTERDAM called at Duins from 14 till 21-10-1749. and at S. Tiago from 13 till 16-11-1749.
Some of the 20 persons who disembarked at the Cape went over to the STRALEN (see 3484). During the voyage 3 soldiers probably became seafarers.
The FORTUIN called at S. Tiago from 01 till 08-02-1750. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia, 31-12-1755.
The IMMAGONDA called at S. Tiago from 01 till 07-02-1750.
The 6 passengers included one female slave. The KIEVIETS-HEUVEL called at S. Tiago from 01 till 07-02-1750.
During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer. See also 3477.
Storm and thunder drove the HAZE beyond the Cape; it called at Delagoa from 11-07 till 08-08-1750. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 31-12-1756.
The NAARSTIGHEID called at Duins (twice: from 10 till 21-04 and 26 till 28-04-1750) and at Portsmouth (03 till 17-05-1750).
Prayo on S. Tiago (19 till 23-05-1750). It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay from 07 till 24-08-1750.
The OOSTKAPELLE called at S. Tiago from 16 till 21-05-1750. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
From 19 till 27-05-1750 the BROUWER was at S. Tiago.
disembarked at Batavia. As appears from a resolution of gouverneur-generaal en raden the KLEVERSKERKE was wrecked during a voyage to Macassar in 1761.
The LANGEWIJK called at Duins (26 till 29-04) and at S. Tiago (25 till 28-05-1750). It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay The 52 soldiers who disembarked at Batavia included 7 gunners

From 18 till 20-05-1750 the ADMIRAAL TROMP was at S. Tia go. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay, 31-07 till 09-08 1750. The ship was sold in the Indies on 25-08-1763.

The 92 soldiers who embarked at the Rammekens included 10 gunners; they disembarked at Batavia. The ZAAMSLAG called at S. Tiago (from 22 till 27-05-1750) and, after a vain attempt to round Cape Augustin, at S. Angra on Terceira (from 26-08 till 24-09-1750). Jakob Hogermolen died before reaching the Cape: Leendert Fruit van Hertog succeeded him as master. The ship also called at Bantam, where 64 soldiers disembarked.

After having lost its rudder on the Flemish Banks, 10-05. the OS-DORP called at Duins (from 13-05 till 21-07-1750). This delay was due to a mutiny. 19 Mutineers were taken over by a man-of-war. The OSDORP also called at Bantam, where 52 soldiers disembarked.
The 119 soldiers who embarked at Rammekens included 11 gunners; they all disembarked at Batavia.

till 04-12-1750): 21 seafarers, 3 soldiers and 2 craftsmen disembarked or deserted. The ship also called at Surinam (from 21-02 till 10-05-1751): 28 seafarers and 13 soldiers deserted, one chief mate and 4 soldiers embarked. From 18-07 till 13-08-1751 the OOSTHUIZEN was at S. Tiago: 2 seafarers and 3 soldiers went ashore, 4 seafarers were taken over from the LUCHTENBURG (see 3525) and the TULPENBURG (see 3526). Some of the 4 seafarers who disembarked at the Cape went to the LUCHTENBURG.
The 6 passengers who embarked at the Cape were bandits. The STANDVASTIGHEID called at Bantam, where 62 soldiers went ashore.
From 24-10 till 4-11-1750 the LEKKERLAND called at S. Tiago. At Bantam 71 soldiers disembarked.
The HARTEKAMP called at Duins (25-09 till 04-10), and at S. Tiago (11 till 18-11-1750).

The 6 passengers included 3 female slaves. The GIESSEN-BURG called at Duins (20 till 28-11-1750) and at S. Tiago (25-12-1750 till 02-01-1751).

The GUSTAAF WILLEM called at Duins (20 till 28-11-1750) and at S. Tiago (25-12-1750 till 02-01-1751). At Bantam 122 seafarers and 85 soldiers disembarked. During the voyage one soldier probably became a seafarer.

In 1757 the ARNESTIJN was laid up and sold at Batavia.
From 09 till 17-03-1751 the HOF D'UNO was at S. Tiago. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay
The SCHAKENBOS did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay. During the voyage one soldier probably became a seafarer. On 17-02-1752 the SCHAKENBOS was wrecked in Manipa Strait.
The BAARZANDE called at S. Tiago from 05 till 08-07-1751.
From 21 till 26-07-1751 the EENDRACHT called at S. Tiago.

On 06-10-1752 the PIJLSWAART set out for the first time, but on 12-10 it returned to Texel. The ship called at S. Tiago (08 till 15-12-1752), where one seafarer deserted. During the voyage one soldier probably became a seafarer. The cargo consisted among other things of f 250,004 in cash.

The cargo of the BLOEMENDAAL consisted among other things of f 215,629 in cash. In 1756 the ship was wrecked off Surat.

The DIEMEN carried among other things f 103,542 in cash. 3577/- Is the third voyage of this ship, which during its previous two voyages was called KASTEEL VAN TILBURG (see 3468/7366). In 1756 it was wrecked in the Indies.

The 8 passengers included 4 female slaves. The RHOON called at Duins twice: from 14 till 15-04 and from 16-04 till 03-05-1753, where one seafarer died. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The MEERVLIET called at Bahia de Todos os Santos (All Saints' Bay) from 03-12-1753 till 20-01-1754, where 20 seafarers deserted or died. The 6 seafarers who disembarked at the Cape included one condemned person, he was sent back to patria on the OSDORP (see 7419). The ship carried among other things f 74,550 in cash. It was laid up at Malacca on 31-12-1758.
The cargo of the VOORZICHTIGHEID consisted among other things of f 60,005 in cash. On 08-06-1757 the VOORZICHTIGHEID, loaded with rice, ran aground at the Cape and was wrecked.

return to Texel. The ship called at S. Tiago from 19 till 24-11-1753. It carried f 42,700 in cash. The PRINSES CAROLINA replaced the AMSTELLAND, wrecked in September 1751 at the island Sylt (see 3530).

An earlier attempt to depart from Texel took place on 08-10, but three days later the ship had to return. The PRINSES VAN ORANJE called at S. Tiago from 10 till 24-11-1753. The ship was sold in the Indies on 21-02-1764.
On 08-10 the KEUKENHOF sailed out for the first time, but three days later it had to return to Texel. Gerrit Bot died before reaching the Cape, Isaak Grindet succeeded him as master.

The RUITEVELD set out for the first time on 08-10, but three days later it returned. The ship carried among other things f 344,896 in cash.
The HUIGENWAARD called at Portsmouth from 11 till 13-11-1753, where one seafarer deserted. In 1758 the ship was sold at Batavia.

The JAGER called at S. Tiago from 06 till 12-01-1754, where one seafarer deserted. The two passengers who embarked at the Cape were a condemned seafarer and an ex-exile who for ten years had been banished from Batavia. During the voyage one soldier possibly became a seafarer. Since March 1755 the JAGER was called BAARZANDE (see 7453 etc.).
During the voyage one soldier probably became a seafarer.
The OUDKARSPEL called at Duins three times: from 04 till 09-01, from 11 till 22-01, and from 24 till 28-01-1754.

The RADERMACHER did not call at the Cape but at False Bay from 20-07 till 13-08-1754.

The OVERNES called at S. Tiago from 27-06 till 09-07-1757, where two seafarers and one soldier died; two seafarers went to the SPAARZAAMHEID (see 3703), two soldiers deserted. In 1762 the GETROUWIGHEID ran aground in the Bay of Goa and was wrecked.

The VISVLIET called at Duins, 09 till 10-08-1761: one seafarer died. Between the Cape and Batavia 2 soldiers were taken over by an English ship.

Spithead 23 seafarers were taken over by the OOSTERBEEK (see 3831). On 12-07-1762 the ship took over 25 seafarers from the IMMAGONDA (see 3827). After having arrived at Batavia it sailed on to China.

132 Of the 151 seafarers who disembarked at the Cape went to other ships; many of the 172 embarking soldiers carne from other ships. The BLIJDORP called at Tuticorin in India (23-06 till 21-08-1762): 11 seafarers were admitted to the hospital, one seafarer died, 172 soldiers and one passenger went ashore. During the voyage at least 9 soldiers possibly became seafarers.
seafarers were taken over by the ASCHAT (see 3825).
The 94 disembarking seafarers and soldiers at the Cape included 10 seafarers and 65 soldiers who went to other ships.
Between patria and the Cape one seafarer and two soldiers were pressed by the English. The 22 seafarers who went ashore at the Cape included two deserters.

The OOSTERBEEK called at Duins (17 till 22-12) and at Spithead (29-12-1761 till 23-01-1762); at Spithead the ship took over 23 seafarers from the ASCHAT (see 3825). Before sailing to Bengal it first called at Ceylon. See also 3834. In 1765 the OOSTER-BEEK ran aground at East Java and was wrecked.

01-03-1762 Is the final date of departure of the WALCHEREN; on 25-01-1762 the ship vainly tried to sail out for the first time. The 133 persons who disembarked at the Cape included 12 seafarers and 98 soldiers who went to the OOSTERBEEK (see 3831).

The WELGELEGEN called at Duins, 20 till 21-04-1762: 3 seafarers and 2 soldiers were pressed by the English. The 17 seafarers who went ashore there included one deserter.
deserted. On 05-08-1763 the AMSTELVEEN was wrecked off the Arabian Coast.

From 07 till 15-06 the LEIMUIDEN was at S. Vincente: 7 soldiers deserted. On 16-06 one seafarer and one craftsmen were pressed by an English ship. The ship also called at S. Tiago, 17 till 25-06-1762: two soldiers were taken aboard.

The VLISSINGEN called at Portsmouth (23 till 27-08) and at S. Vincente (26-09 till 04-10-1762); at Portsmouth 3 seafarers were pressed by the English, one seafarer died; at S. Vincente one seafarer and 6 soldiers deserted; one Frenchman was taken aboard as seafarer.
From 24-09 till 02-10-1762 the HUIS TE BIJWEG was at Duins. The ship sailed on to China.
The SLOTEN called at Spithead, 24-09 till 02-10-1762. The ship sailed on to China.
The 16 soldiers who went ashore at the Cape included one deserter. The OVERSCHIE was laid up in the Indies, 20-10-1764.
24 seafarers who went ashore at the Cape included 5 deserters.
persons who went ashore at the Cape included 7 seafarers and 6 soldiers who deserted.
After having arrived at Batavia the WESTERVELD sailed on to China.

The BAARZANDE called at S. Tiago, 04 till 14-01-1763. 3851/7649 Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its first two voyages and its third outward-voyage was called JAGER (numbers of the third voyage: 3612/7453).
The LEKKERLUST called at S. Tiago (04 till 14-01-1763): 3 seafarers and one soldier disembarked.

From 04 till 14-01-1763 the DRIE PAPEGAAIEN was at S. Tiago: one seafarer and two soldiers went missing, one seafarer died. The ship also called at Bantam (23-06-1763): 4 seafarers went to another ship.
The 22 seafarers who went ashore at the Cape included one deserter.

The ERFPRINS did not call at the Cape but at False Bay; the 31 soldiers who went ashore there included one deserter. 3859/7675 is the fourth voyage of this ship, which during its first two voyages was called DELFT (numbers of the second voyage: 3696/7518).
Tiago, 31-05 till 04-06-1763: two soldiers and one craftsmen disembarked, 8 passengers came aboard. The ship was sold in the Indies, 31-12-1768.

The EENDRACHT did not call at the Cape but at False Bay; the 58 persons who went ashore there included 2 seafarers and 2 soldiers who deserted. 3861/7689 Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its first two voyages was called ELSWOUD (numbers of the second voyage: 3503/7398).

In 1766 the GIESSENBURG, sailing to Banda. was wrecked.
/- Is the third voyage of this ship, which during its first voyage was called MARIENBOS (see 3605/7508). The ship was sold in the Indies, 12-01-1770.

Tiago 3 seafarers and one soldier died, 3 soldiers deserted, one seafarer and one soldier were taken aboard. At Tuticorin 24 seafarers, 148 soldiers and 9 passengers went ashore, 11 seafarers and 11 soldiers died; 2 seafarers came aboard.

The 60 persons who went ashore at the Cape included 6 seafarers and 3 soldiers who deserted.

16-10-1763 Is the final date of departure of the RUITEVELD; on 28-09-1763 the ship set out for the first time, but 16 days later it returned to Texel (14-10); adverse wind caused this delay. After having arrived at Batavia the ship sailed on to China.
From 07 till 10-11-1763 the WILDRIJK was at Duins. In 1766 the ship was sold in the Indies.
In 1766 the IMMAGONDA was laid up in the Indies.

From 29-01 till 03-02-1764 the ship was at S. Tiago: one seafarer deserted. On 12-01-1770 the BOSSCHENHOVE was laid up and sold in the Indies.
The VELSEN called at S. Tiago (02 till 14-02-1764): 23 seafarers and 9 soldiers deserted or died.
The WESTFRIESLAND called at S. Tiago (probably from 29-01 till 03-02-1764): 2 seafarers and 6 soldiers deserted, one soldier died. The 2 passengers who embarked at the Cape were condemned persons.
The LIEFDE called at Torbay (30-12-1763 till 16-01-1764) and at Portsmouth (20 till 29-01-1764). In 1768 the ship was laid up in the Indies.

15-11-1764 Is the final date of departure of the VREDENHOF; on 08-10-1764 it sailed out for the first time, but it was forced by adverse wind to return to Texel two days later. After having arrived at Batavia the ship sailed on the China.

According to a letter sent from the Cape the GEINWENS departed from Texel with 350 persons aboard. At the departure from the Cape the crew consisted of 211 men. In 1776 GEINWENS was wrecked off Punto Gale.

On 18-11-1771 the LEIDERDORP set out for the first time; it had to return to Texel the next day. A second attempt to depart, 07-12-1771, also failed; back at Texel: 22-12. The third and final date of departure was 30-12-1771. In 1776 the LEIDERDORP was sold in the Indies.
The SCHOONZICHT was laid up in the Indies, 01-01-1780.
The ZON was bound for the Cape.

The GROENENDAAL made two earlier attempts to put out: 18-11-1771 (return to Texel the next day) and 07-12 1771 (back at Texel: 12-12); 31-12-1771 was the final date of departure. According to data recorded at the Cape the ship left from Texel with 249 persons aboard.

The HONKOOP made two earlier attempts to put out: 18-11-1771(back at Texel the next day) and 07-12-1771 (return 19-12); 31-12-1771 was the final date of departure. According to data recorded at the Cape the ship departed from Texel with a crew consisting of 282 persons.

The HUIS TER MEIJEN made two earlier attempts to put out: 18-11-1771 (back at Texel the next day) and 07-12-1771 (return: 19-12); 31-12-1771 was the final date of departure. According to data recorded at the Cape the HUIS TER MEIJEN departed from Texel with a crew consisting of 248 persons.

On 05-12-1771 the HUIS TE KROOSWIJK attempted to put out for the first time, two weeks later it had to return to Goeree. The ship called at Spithead, 24-02-1772.

The OOSTEREEM flew the Prussian flag. The ship was bound for China; on 21-01-1783, however, it ran aground at Goodwin's Sand and was wrecked. 4406/- Is the second voyage of this ship, which during the preceding voyage (4184/8014) was called VENUS.

Pieter Modderman was master, when the ship arrived at the Cape. After having called at Batavia the AURICH possibly sailed on to China. 4407/8095 Is the sixth voyage of this ship, which during the preceding voyages was called RIDDERKERK (numbers of the fifth voyage: 4297/8032).

At the departure from Texel both the VROUWE MARIA KORNELIA and the TRINCONOMALE (4632) were escorted by two Dutch men-of-war. After having arrived at Batavia the VROUWE MARIA KORNELIA sailed on to China, where it cast anchor on 26-10-1789.
See the VROUWE MARIA KORNELIA (4631).
S. Tiago, 25-03 till 03-04-1789. In 1793 or 1794 the ship was sold at Batavia.

The VROUWE SARA HENDRINA was bound for the Cape.
Soon after having departed from Goeree the EEN-PARIGHEID's masts were severely damaged. For that reason the ship had to call at Duins, 09 till 23-07-1789.
According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 200 men. The MENTOR called at Duins, 24 till 27-07-1789.
According to K.A. 4317 the departing crew consisted of 293 men.
called at Duins, 04 till 08-08-1789. In 1793 the ship was sold in Bengal.
The STERRESCHANS was bound for the Cape. On 20-05-1793 the ship ran aground at the Cape and was wrecked.
After having arrived at Batavia the VASCO DA GAMA sailed on to China.
In 1793 or 1794 the VOORSCHOTEN was sold at Batavia.
According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 355 men. The ship went on to China.
the GOUVERNEUR-GENERAAL MAATSUIJKER was sold at Batavia.
On 01-12-1789 the CANTON departed from Goeree; five days later it arrived at Texel. Continuing its voyage from Batavia to China the CANTON was wrecked in the South China Sea.
On 01-12-1789 the HOORNWEG departed from Goeree; nine days later the ship arrived at Texel.
The NIEUWSTAD called at Portsmouth, 21 till 28-02-1790.
According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 331 men.
On 19-05-1790 the STAR arrived at False Bay.
In 1793 the BATAVIER ran aground and was wrecked in the Indies
The 27 passengers included 26 Chinese, 11 of them arrived at Batavia.
At Batavia, before sailing back to Texel in 1791/2, the ship's name was altered into TEXELSTROOM (see 8318).
Originally the INDUS departed on 27-08-1790; it had to return to Texel, however. From 10 till 24-09-1790 the ship was at Duins. In 1794 the INDUS was burnt down in the roads of Batavia.
According to K.A. 4328 the departing crew consisted of 286 men.
In 1793 or 1794 the IJSTROOM was sold at Batavia.
According to K.A. 4328 three passengers were aboard the BLITTERSWIJK, when it departed from Texel. The ship called at Duins, 06 till 09-10-1790, and went from Batavia to China.
In 1793 the WILLEM DE VIERDE was taken by the French in Sunda Strait.
From 17-10-1790 till 21-02-1791 the VALK was at Gluckstadt. On 27-02-1791 the ship was wrecked at the banks off Yarmouth.
In 1796 the CANDIA was sold and broken up at Batavia.

According to K.A. 4328 nine passengers were aboard the SPA-RENRIJK, when it departed from Texel. In 1794 the ship was sold at Batavia. 4684.1- Is the third voyage of this ship, which during its first voyage (4410/8099) was called POTSDAM.
The NEGOTIE was bound for Ceylon. On 26 and 27-11-1790, however, the ship was wrecked and went to pieces off Texel.
Torbay (14 till 27-02-1791). In 1795 the MEERWIJK was sold at Batavia.
At the departure from Texel the CHRISTOFFEL COLUMBUS, the CONSTITUTIE (4689), the KRAAI (4690), the SCHAGEN (4691), and the ZAANSTROOM (4692) were accompanied by a Dutch man-of-war.
During the voyage the CONSTITUTIE lost all its topmasts. See the CHRISTOFFEL COLUMBUS (4688).
Date of departure from the Cape unknown. See the CHRISTOF-FEL COLUMBUS (4688).

The ZAANSTROOM was bound for the Cape. On 28-02-1791, however, the ship ran aground off Barfleur in France. See the CHRISTOFFEL COLUMBUS (4688).
According to K.A. 4328 the departing crew consisted of 301 men. At the Cape many soldiers embarked. Eventually the ship was sold at Batavia.
The ZEELAND carried many soldiers to Batavia and went on to China.
According to K.A. 4328 the departing crew consisted of 372 men.
According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 207 men. The JAVA carried many soldiers to Batavia. In 1796 the ship was laid up at Batavia.

The VASCO DA GAMA called at Portsmouth, 03-01 till 16-02-1792. After 1795 the ship was broken up at Batavia. See the BUITENVERWACHTING (4712).
From 25-02 till 30-03-1792 the WESTKAPELLE was at S. Tiago.
Originally the GOUDA sailed from Texel on 21-12-1791; five days later, however, the ship returned.

The HILVERSBEEK called at Duins (departure: 02-06-1792). At (or before) the Cape Jan Jobst Droop succeeded Klaas Voet as master. The ship carried many soldiers to Ceylon.
One day after its departure from Texel the BERKHOUT had to be towed into Dover; there the ship was laid up.
In 1796 the TEILINGEN was sold and broken up at Batavia.

The ST. LAURENS called at Duins (17 till 20-07-1792) and at S. Tiago (01 till 10-09-1792). In 1795 or 1796 the ship was broken up at Batavia.

On 04-08-1793 the Company's authorities sent the ship to the Delagoa River in order to look for the homeward-bound DEMERARY (8363), which had departed from Batavia in February, 1793, and was missing since. Eventually the STAR was taken by the English.
On 15-07-1795 the LUCHTBOL was sold to the Danes at Bengal.
there it was taken by the English, when they captured the city.
The 23 passengers indicated in the first column were Chinese; 20 of them arrived at Batavia.

From 28-09 till 24-11-1793 the HAASJE was at Plymouth. Early in May, 1797, the HAASJE, which had been severely damaged during a storm, cast anchor off the mouth of the Delagoa River; on 27-05-1797 it was taken there by an English fishing-boat, assisted by a Portuguese ship.
The VREDENBURG called at Plymouth, 28-09 till 24-11-1793. The date of departure from the Cape is unknown. In 1795 or 1796 the ship was sold at Batavia.

The 44 passengers indicated in the first column included 39 Chinese; 37 of them arrived at Batavia. After having called at Batavia the HERTOG VAN BRUNSWIJK possibly sailed on to China. In 1795 or 1796 the ship was wrecked off Batavia.
According to K.A. 43936 the DORDRECHT had taken in its cargo at Riga. 4756/8380 Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its first voyage (4400/8087) was called BERLIN.

The 26 passengers indicated in the first column included 23 Chinese; they all arrived at Batavia. After having called at Batavia the ZEELELIE sailed on to China.
From Texel the ZEEMEEUW sailed to Rammekens; there it finally put to sea on 02-02-1794.
Batavia.
In 1795 or 1796 the WESTKAPELLE was sold at Batavia.
On 25-03-1794 the FAAM was taken by the French and brought to Brest.
According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 231 men. After 1795 the BUITENVERWACHTING was sold at Batavia.

On 23-04-1794 the VROUWE MARIA GEERTRUIDA sailed from Rammekens to Texel. Twenty days after its final departure from Texel the ship was seized by the French; later that year it was recaptured by the English and taken to Plymouth, where it arrived on 09-06-1794.
On 23-04-1794 the ONDERNEMING sailed from Rammekens to Texel.
On 23-04-1794 the ZUIDPOOL sailed from Rammekens to Texel.
On 23-06-1794 the BERLICUM sailed from Rammekens to Texel. On 15-02-1796 the ship was confiscated by the English at Ceylon.
On 23-06-1794 the JONGE BONIFACIUS sailed from Rammekens to Texel.
The CASTOR was bound for the Cape. Eventually the ship was taken by the English.
On 23-06-1794 the EENSGEZINDHEID sailed from Rammekens to Texel. On 15-02-1796 the ship was seized by the English at Ceylon.
On 22-05-1794 the MARIA LOUISA sailed from Goeree to Texel. On 21-10-1795 the ship was captured by the English off the Cape and taken to the Cape.
wrecked.
The RESOLUTIE called at Portsmouth, 09 till 11-09-1794. One source indicates, that in 1797 the ship still was in active service in the Indies.

The NIEUWLAND was bound for China. The ship called at Duins; arrival: 19-12-1794. On 10-01-1795 the NIEUWLAND cast anchor at Plymouth; there the English put an embargo on the ship and finally confiscated it.
In August 1795, the GEERTRUIDA was captured by the English at the Cape.
The OOSTHUIZEN was bound for China Six days after its departure from Texel the ship called at the Scilly Islands In December 1795, the OOSTIIUIZEN was confiscated by the English.
The WESTERMEER was bound for Batavia. Four days after the departure from Texel, however, the ship was seized by the French.
The WILLEMSTAD EN BOETSELAAR was bound for Batavia. In August 1795, the ship was captured by the English at the Cape.
The ZORG called at Plymouth, 26-12-1794 till 04-11-1795. Three days after the departure from Plymouth the ship ran aground off Boulogne and was wrecked.

Before the ARNHEM had left the Sunda Strait, two masters had died: Jan Rotgans and Pieter \nJansz. de Vries; the third one, Van Bergen, was dismissed at the Cape for being unable to maintain order. His successor was Jan Simonsz. Klos.
AVONDSTER returned to Batavia because of leakage (28-02-1657). Part of the cargo was taken over by the PAREL. It stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the Bay of Gale (Ceylon) (02-07-1659).
Departure from Cape with 157 men.

Both ships lost each other out of sight, 29/30-03-1659. The ERASMUS sailed via the Comoro Istands and Madagascar because of damage. At the Cape it waited for the return fleet of 18-12-1659. The ship called at St Helena. The crew included 16 Portuguese prisoners.

stow-aways were put aboard the ANKEVEEN at the Cape (see 0930). Via St. Helena.
Second return fleet (5489-5490) under command of Johan Bouchellon. The crew included 7 passengers.

First return fleet (5491-5497) under command of Arnold de Vlaming van Oudshoorn(+) aboard the WAPEN VAN HOLLAND and Jakob Willemsz. (vice-comm. +). At the Cape the fleet waited for the return fleet of 30-01-1662. Johan van der Laan became the new commander. The ARNHEM was wrecked at Brandao, an island east of Madagascar (12-02-1662); about 80 survivors reached Mauritius and were picked up later.
Was wrecked in the Indian Ocean during a storm at 25/26'S. (10-02-1662).

The SPREEUW sailed on its own with message of the loss of Taiwan.

First return fleet (5501-5508) under command of Herman Klenke van Odessen aboard the WAPEN VAN AMSTER-DAM. At the Cape the MEIBOOM joined the fleet. Unsuccessful voyage of discovery to the non-existent island New Helena.
Joined the fleet of 26-12-1662 at the Cape. This adviesjacht brought the message of the Dutch conquest of Cochin
Second return fleet (5510-5511) under command of Kornelis Vonk.
and the LOOSDUINEN (5522) joined the fleet.
Aboard the MAARSSEVEEN was Adriaan van der Meide, vice-commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was wrecked in the battle of Lowestoft against the English, 13-06-1665.
The NAGELBOOM was hired by the Admiralties to fight the English; it was taken by the English on 13-06-1665.
Aboard the ORANJE was Dirk Steur, commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was hired by the Admiralties to fight the English; it was burnt in the battle of Lowestoft, 13-06-1665.
Four stowaways discovered.

KOGGE and the NIEU-WENHOVE (5534 and 5535) joined the fleet. The combined fleet sailed via Bergen (Norway) because of the war; 12-08-1665: battle in the Bay of Bergen against an English fleet (25 men killed and 70 wounded). After the departure from Bergen two ships were taken by the English (see below). The AMSTELLAND returned to Bergen on 16-09-1665; departure: in October. On 25-10-1665 the ship was wrecked east of Terschelling; its cargo was mainly saved.
Via Bergen (08-08 till 02-09-1665).
Via Bergen, departure on 02-09-1665.
Via Bergen (08-08 till 02-09-1665). Taken on 13-09-1665 by the English at Dogger Bank.

storm near the Cape (Febr. 1665).

02-09-1665); on 13-09-1665 it was taken by the English at Dogger Bank.

Via Bergen (08-08 till 02-09-1665) and Denmark (Kronborg). Returned under convoy in the fleet of schout-bij-nacht Stachouwer of the Admiralty of Friesland.

Second return fleet (5534-5535), joined the first return fleet (see 5523) at the Cape. According to Daghregister 1665 the KOGGE carried a cargo of 88,576. The ship called at Bergen; departure: 02-09-1665. Later on it returned to Norway (Flecker O and Kristiansand).
The crew included 2 passengers.

Separate fleet (5536-5537) from Bengal via Ceylon (departure on 29-12-1665) and Malabar; joined the fleet of 30-01-1666 at the Cape. The original cargo of the KALF From Bengal had an invoice value of 190,754. The ship sailed v ia Bergen. It was wrecked in the Vlie, 22 men were saved.
Original cargo from Bengal: 364,044. The VENENBURG was taken by the English.
with 356 men and 11 passengers. At the Cape the KALF and the VENENBURG (5536 and 5537) joined the fleet.
Jakob Kauw, commandeur of the return fleet.
was repaired at Panjon. It sailed via Saldanha Bay (arrival: 25-04-1666). At the Cape the problem of leakage occurred again.
Separate fleet (5543-5545) from Bengal via Ceylon (19-01-1667) and Malabar, joined the return fleet of 26-01-1667 at the Cape. Original cargo of the CECILIA from Batavia: 17,415.

(5554). At he Cape the CECI-LIA, the OPPERDOES, and the SPARENDAM (5543-5545) joined the fleet. The crew of the AMERSFOORT included one passenger.

First return fleet (5555-5557) under command of Jan van de Werf, master of the WAPEN VAN HOORN (5556).
Jan van de Werve was commandeur of the return fleet. According to K.A. 1156 the cargo was destined for the chamber of Hoorn.

Second return fleet (5558-5563) under command of Van der Laan aboard the HOLLANDSE TUIN (5562) and Wagenaar aboard the WAPEN VAN MIDDELBURG (5560). At the Cape the AMERONGEN, the JONGE PRINS. the VRIJHEID, and the SPREEUW (5564-5567) joined the fleet.
Aboard the WAPEN VAN MIDDELBURG was Wagenaar, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
Laan. commandeur of the return fleet.
Third return fleet (5564-5566). Joined the fleet of 07-12-1667 at the Cape. The crew of the AMERONGEN included 3 passengers.
carried a cargo of 170,212. The ship joined the fleet of 07-12 and that of 24-12-1667 at the Cape.

First return fleet (5571-5578) under command of Johan Thijssen aboard the ZUIDPOLSBROEK (5578). Seven heavy storms harassed the fleet before it reached the Cape. The fleet of 14-12 and that of 20-12-1668 joined the command of Johan Thijssen. According to Daghregister 1668/9 the BATAVIA arrived at the Cape on 01-03-1669. The crew included one passenger.

The crew included one passenger. Aboard the OOSTENBURG was Enoch Poolvoet, commandeur of the return fleet.

Second return fleet (5600-5604) under command of Johannes Massis aboard the DAMIATE. Joined the fleet of 18-11-1669 at the Cape. The crew of the DAMIATE included 5 passengers.

First return fleet (5609-5616) under command of IJsbrand Goske aboard the STICHT VAN UTRECHT (5614). At the Cape the HUIS TE VELSEN (5617) and the fleet of 19-12-1670 from Ceylon joined this fleet. According to Daghregister 1671 the fleet left the Cape on 16-03-1671.
STICHT VAN UTRECHT was IJsbrand Goske. commandeur of the return fleet.
Joined the fleet of 19-11-1670 at the Cape.

Second return fleet (5618-5621) under command of Pieter Koopman aboard the VRIJHEID (5620). At the Cape the SPANBROEK (5624) joined the fleet. According to K.A. 3984 the fleet left the Cape on 20-03-1671.
The crew included 2 passengers. Aboard the VRIJHEID was Pieter Koopman, commandeur of the return fleet.

After a dinner at the Cape the master was stabbed in a quarrel and died. His successor was Isaak Fontein.

aboard the TERNATE (5632), and schout-bij-nacht Sanderus aboard the DELFSHAVEN. At the Cape the fleet of 20-01-1672 from Ceylon and the fleet of 04-02-1672 joined this fleet. According to K.A. 3984 the combined fleet left the Cape on 19-04-1672.

Second return fleet (5640-5641); joined the fleet of 20-12-1671 at the Cape. According to K.A. 3984 the combined fleet left the Cape on 19-04-1672.

Return fleet (5642-5647) under command of Abraham Huibrechtsen aboard the WAPEN VAN VEERE (5647) and Eduard Goudsmit aboard the PIJNACKER (5645). The ALPHEN was taken by the English at St. Helena, May 1673.

The EUROPA originally was a French ship, captured in the Indies (October 1672). According to Daghregister 167314 the ship left the Cape on 10-05-1673. At St. Helena it was taken by the English, May 1673.
Due to wrong instructions the PAPENBURG was taken by the English off Texel, August 1673.
Aboard the PIJNACKER was Eduard Goudsmit, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
Aboard the WAPEN VAN VEERE was Abraham Huibrechtsen, commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was taken by the English at St. Helena, May 1673.
Sailed via Bergen (Norway).

Return fleet (5650-5658) under command of Nikolaas de Rooi aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN (5654), Jan Blauwmeulen aboard the MIDDELBURG (5655), and Jan Lambertsz. Radder aboard the BUREN (5653). At the Cape the ZWEMMER (5659) joined the fleet. The BAARS carried rice to the Cape and sailed on to patria.
Acc. to Daghregister 1674 the ship arrived at the Cape on 02 or 04-05-1674.
Aboard the BUREN was Jan Lambertsz. Radder, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
Aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN was Nikolaas de Rooi, commandeur of the return fleet.

The MIDDELBURG sailed via Anjouan (09-06-1674) and the Mayotte Islands (12-08 till 03-10-1674), meeting with many difficulties and loosing about 60 men, The ship joined the fleet of 18-11-1674 at the Cape. Aboard the MIDDELBURG was Jan Blauwmeulen, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
Joined the fleet of 04-02-1674 at the Cape.
(5663), and Jakob Ganswijk aboard the VRIJE ZEE (5666). At the Cape the MIDDELBURG (5655) and the KROONVOGEL (5674) joined the fleet.

through Sunda Strait the ship lost sight of the fleet. Due to a French attack it did not call at the Cape, and sailed via Pernambuco (Brazil). Aboard the VRIJE ZEE was Jakob Ganswijk, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
joined the fleet of 28-01-1675 at the Cape. According to Valentijn the Ceylon-fleet departed on 07-01-1675.

Second return fleet (5670-5673) under command of Ludder Brummer aboard the AZIE (5671) and Jakob Valk, master of the WAPEN VAN ZIERIKZEE (5673). At the Cape the Ceylon-fleet of 12-01-1675 joined this fleet.
Aboard the AZIE was Ludder Brummer, commandeur of the return fleet.
The DEN BRIEL sailed from Ceylon and waited in Sunda Strait for the fleet of 28-01-1675.
return fleet.

The fleet (5687-5688) from Ceylon joined the fleet of 21-11-1675 at the Cape. According to Daghregister 1676 the BEEMSTER departed on 17-11-1675 from Ceylon, and arrived on 13-03-1676 at the Cape.

Second return fleet (5689-5691) under command of Klaas Voogd, master of the CEYLON (5690). The crew of the ALEXANDER included 72 seafarers.
Klaas Voogd was commandeur of the return fleet.
Acc. to Daghregister 1676: cargo 163,760. Amongst the crew were 81 seafarers.

First return fleet (5692-5700) under command of Gijsbert David Strandwijk aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN (5696), Jan Bartelsz. Tand aboard the PRINS WILLEM HENDRIK (5700), and Laurens Martensz. Suiker aboard the DELFSHAVEN (5693). According to Valentijn the fleet departed on 2111-1676 from Batavia.
Aboard the DELFSHAVEN was Laurens Martensz. Suiker, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
Aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN was Gijsbert David Strandwijk, commandeur of the return fleet.
Aboard the PRINS WILLEM HENDRIK was Jan Bartelsz. Tand, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
The fleet (5701-5702) from Ceylon joined perhaps the return fleet of 12-02-1677 at the Cape. \nAcc. to K.A. 1204 the Ceylon-fleet arrived at the Cape on 31-03-1677.

Willem Hagedoorn was commandeur of the second return fleet (5703-5706); it joined perhaps the fleet of 26-01-1677 from CeyIon at the Cape. According to Hudde 20 the WAPEN VAN ALKMAAR arrived on 04-11-1677 in patria.
According to Hudde 20 the GELE BEER arrived on 04-11-1677 in patria.

First return fleet (5707-5712) under command of Konstantijn Raust aboard the AZIE, Hendrik van Rede aboard the KORT-GENE (5708) and Jan van Oosterwijk aboard the VRIJE ZEE (5711). The fleet revictuated at Pernambuco(Brazil).
Aboard the KORTGENE was Hendrik van Rede, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
Aboard the VRIJE ZEE was Jan van Oosterwijk, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
The fleet (5713-5714) from Ceylon did not call at the Cape, but called at Fernando Noronha (27-04 till 02-06-1678).
Second return fleet (5715-5717) under command of Jan Hendriksz. Boon, master of the POULERON (5717). Aboard the BLOEMENDAAL there were probably also seafarers privately recruited by the master.
Aboard the KRIJGSMAN there were probably also seafarers privately recruited by the master.
Jan Hendriksz. Boon was commandeur of the return fleet.
Acc. to Valentijn: cargo 4,157.

(5721-5729) under command of Jakob van der Waayen aboard the AFRIKA, Bartholomeus Nouters aboard the HENDRIK MAURITS (5724), and Johannes Brakes aboard the HUIS TE ZILVERSTEIN (5729).  Acc. to K.A. 3992 the first seven ships departed on 15-03-1679, and acc. to Coolhaas IV on 13-03-1679.
Acc. to Hudde 20 132 seafarers and 40 soldiers on board.
Aboard the HENDRIK MAURITS was Bartholomeus Nouters, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
36 Seafarers had been privately recruited by the master of the ship.
Sailed ahead of the fleet and joined it at the Cape.
Joined the return fleet during the voyage; according to Hudde 20, 135 seafarers on board. Aboard the HUIS TE ZILVER-STEIN was Johannes Brakel, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
Sailed alone.
Sailed alone. According to K.A.1231, fol. 1618. cargo 54,065.

First return fleet (5732-5737) under command of Sybrand Abbema aboard the LAND VAN SCHOUWEN (5736), Andries Bogaard aboard the EUROPA (5734), and Dirk Timonsz. de Jonge aboard the SCHIELAND (5735). At the Cape the fleet of 09-01-1680 from Ceylon joined this fleet. In addition to the crew, 36 sick seafarers were aboard the fleet. The 60 seafarers aboard the SINT ANDRIES had been privately recruited by the master. According to Hudde 20 departure from Batavia on 11-12-1679.
The 18 impotenten were soldiers.
The 19 impotenten were soldiers. Aboard the EUROPA was Andries Bogaard, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.

van Goens aboard the HUIS TE MERWEDE. The Cape was passed by on 23-05-1680.

First return fleet (5742-5745) under command of Rijklof van Goens Junior aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN (5744) and Jakob Geus aboard the CHINA (5743). They were ordered to wait at the Cape until 30-03-1681 for the second return fleet (see below); only the HUIS TE ZILVERSTEIN (5748) succeeded in joining the fleet in time.
Aboard the CHINA was Jakob Geus, vice-commandeur of the return fleet.
Aboard the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN was Rijklof van Goens Junior, commandeur of the return fleet.

master: Kornelis de Keizer or Kornelis Mol

particulars: Second return fleet (5746-5748) under command of Huibert Barendsz. Gruit aboard the EILAND MAURITIUS (5747). The 15 passengers aboard the BLAUWE HULK included 11 imprisoned criminals.
The 12 passengers included 8 imprisoned criminals. Aboard the EILAND MAURITIUS was Huibert Barendsz. Gruit, commandeur of the return fleet.
The 12 passengers included 11 imprisoned criminals. The HUIS TE ZILVERSTEIN joined the return fleet of 29-11-1680 at the Cape.
Third return fleet (5751-5752). The master died at the Cape.
Acc. to Daghregister 168011: cargo of 605,705.
Fourth return fleet (5753-5754). \nAcc. to Valentijn the fleet departed on 21-03-1681 from Batavia.
Jan Wittebol is also mentioned as master.

First return fleet (5755-5757) under command of Rijklof van Goens Senior aboard the LAND VAN SCHOUWEN(5757). At the Cape the second return fleet of 20-12-1681, the ships of 20-01-1682 from Ceylon, and the BURCHT VAN LEIDEN (5763) joined this fleet; Leendert Maas, master of the LAND VAN SCHOUWEN, became vice-commandeur and embarked on the HOLLANDSE TUIN (5758).
aboard the HOLLANDSE TUIN.
storm off Cape Agulhas. It joined the return fleet of 26-11-1681 at the Cape. At the Cape vice-commandeur Leendert Maas embarked on the HOLLANDSE TUIN (See also 5757).
Via Malabar.
The ship from Ceylon (5760-5762) joined the return fleet of 26-11-1681 at the Cape.Acc. to Daghregister 1681 the WESTERAMSTEL arrived on 15-04-1682 at the Cape.
Departed from the Cape with the return fleet of 26-11-1681. According to K.A. 1143, fol. 808 the ship left the Cape on 28-08-1682 with a cargo of 425,315.
According to Hudde 10 the crew of the CHINA consisted of 110 seafarers and 37 soldiers. \nAcc. to Valentijn the ships from Ceylon (5764-5766) departed on 30-01-1683.
According to Coolhaas IV the ship departed on 06-06-1683 from the Cape. Acc. to Hudde 10 the crew consisted of 86 seafarers and 18 soldiers.

Return fleet (5767-5774) under command of Hendrik van Oudshoom aboard the TIDORE (5774). The STRIJEN waited for the fleet of 27-02-1683 in Sunda Strait. Originally the WEST-BROEK (5779) and the HUIS TE SPIJK (5777) also belonged to this fleet, but they had to return to Batavia because of leakage.
The AZIE was wrecked on 17'N.

master: Michiel van der Buis or Gijsbert Kraaienstein
particulars: damaged by storms the EUROPA had to call at Mauritius (08-05 till 29-09-1683) and for more than five months at the Cape, where it was repaired. It waited for the return fleet of 26-12-1683.

The OPLETTENDHEID did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. Originally the OPLETTENDHEID was a French ship, called JASON; it was captured by the English (05-02-1745), brought to Batavia (13-02), and sold to the Dutch (16-02).
As the OPLETTENDHEID (7226) the TOEVALLIGHEID originally was a French ship, called HERCULES; it was captured by the English (05-02-1745), brought to Batavia (13-02), and sold to the Dutch (16-02).

On 17-05-1781 the Company's authorities at the Cape sent the AMSTERDAM to Mauritius to assist the French; three and a half weeks later the ship returned to the Cape, 10-08-1781. Early in 1784 the AMSTERDAM was laid up at the Cape.

On 17-05-1781 the BATAVIA departed from the Cape to sail to Mauritius. The ship was severely damaged during a storm, and had to return to the Cape, 10-08-1781. Early in 1783 the BATAVIA was sold to the French.
In June, 1781, the INDIAAN sailed to the Hout Bay. Later on the ship departed from the Cape to sail to Mauritius, but it was missing since.
On 26-06-1781 the NOORDBEEK was captured by the English and taken to Plymouth.
Sailing to patria the GROENENDAAL was seized by the English, probably in 1782.

03-09-1782; arrival at the Cape on 06-09-1782. The ship never returned to patria. In 1784 it made at least one voyage to Mauritius and back to the Cape. Eventually the HUIS TE SPIJK was laid up there, in 1786.

boatname: SENHOR DE BONFIM E SANCTA MARIA
particulars: flew the Portuguese flag. The ship had arrived at the Cape on 12-04-1782. There it was contracted by the V.O.C. According to K.A. 4276, fol. 373 the ship had to sail to Lisbon or to Amsterdam. Its cargo consisted of China tea, carried to the Cape by the HONKOOP (8071), the HOOGKARSPEL (8072), the MIDDELBURG (8073), and the PAREL (8074); in July, 1781, these ships had been captured or burnt down by the English in Saldanha Bay.
The ANGELIQUE BENECH flew the Imperial (i.e. Austrian) flag. According to K.A. 4287 the ship was bound for Lorient.
The KROONPRINS VAN PRUISEN flew the Prussian flag.
The BERLIN flew the Prussian flag. After the return of the ship to patria its name was altered into DORDRECHT (4458/8148).
The FRIEDRICH DER GROSSE flew the Prussian flag.
The MAGDEBURG flew the Prussian flag.
The 144 men, who departed from Batavia, included one passenger. A mutiny was suppressed between Batavia and the Cape.
The DOLFIJN flew the Imperial (i.e. Austrian) flag.

The AURICH flew the Prussian flag. 4407/8095 was the sixth voyage of this ship, which during its preceding voyages was called RIDDERKERK (4297/8032). After the return to patria the ship was renamed RIDDERKERK (4493/-).
A mutiny was suppressed between Batavia and the Cape.
On 30-06-1784 the HOOP went to pieces off the Cape.
After the return of the ship to patria its name was altered into TWEE GEZUSTERS (4502/8175).
The POTSDAM flew the Prussian flag. After the return of the ship to patria its name was altered into SPARENRIJK (4474/8262).
L'HARMONIE flew the French flag.

See also the GANGES (8106). On 29-10-1785 the Heren XV11 decided to lay the MORGENSTER up.
L'ESPERANCE DE LA PAIX flew the French flag.
See also the GANGES (8106).

LA DAME JEANNE flew the Swedish flag. In accordance with the conditions of the contract, signed in patria in March, 1783, by the owners of the ship and representatives of the V.O.C., the DAME JEANNE had sailed on its own account from Lorient in France (departure: 18-05-1783) via the Cape (08-10 till 02-11-1783) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 19-05-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.

The CONCORDE flew the Swedish flag, see LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The CONCORDE had sailed on its own account from Lorient in France (departure: 13-04-1783) via the Cape (28-10 till 16-12-1783) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 27-04-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.

L'AIGLE NOIR flew the Swedish flag, see LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The AIGLE NOIR had sailed on its own account from Lorient in France (departure: 19-05-1783) via the Cape (31-08 till 03-10-1783) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 10-05-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.

The SAINTE THERESE flew the French flag. The ship probably did not call at the Cape. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The SAINTE THERESE had sailed on its own account from Lorient in France (departure: 04-11-1783) via the Cape (arrival: 01-03-1784) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 01-07-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.
(departure: 17-07-1783), probably without calling at the Cape, to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 29-06-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.

MERENBERG, the L00 (8121), the ROZENBURG (8122), the ONZEKERE (8130), the GOUVERNEUR-GENERAAL DE CLERCK (8133), the DRAAK (8134), and the JACHTRUST (8142) were escorted by a Dutch man of war.

Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 05-08-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.
Sailing to the Cape the HARMONIE was wrecked. See also the MEEUWTJE (4477).

Swedish flag. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The CONJUNCTURE had sailed on its own account from Martinique (departure: 10-10-1783) via the Cape (arrival: 18-03-1784) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 04-10-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.
Sailing from Batavia to the Cape the OVERDUIN was wrecked. See also the MEEUWTJE (4477).

LES SIX FRERES new the French flag. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The SIX FRERES had sailed on its own account from Bordeaux (departure: 07-09-1783) via the Cape (arrival: 02-03-1784) to Mauritius. There the ship had officially entered the Company's service. On 04-10-1784 the SIX FRERES arrived at Batavia.
See also the MERENBERG (8120).
Soon after the departure from Batavia the HOORN sprang a leak. The ship possibly had to return. According to K.A. 4289, fol. 464 the master was called Jan Thierens.
Sailing from Batavia to the Cape the BREDENHOF was wrecked.
See also the MERENBERG (8120).
See also the MERENBERG (8120).
On 13-04-1785 the STRALEN arrived at False Bay; four days later the ship sailed to the Cape.
On 04-05-1785 the BREDERODE sank off Cape Agulhas; 80 men were saved.

The CASTRIES flew the French flag. From 27-05- till 22-12-1785 the ship called at Mauritius. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The CASTRIES had sailed on its own account from Bordeaux (departure: 17-05-1783) via the Cape (30-12-1783 till 15-01-1784) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. On 09-11-1784 the ship arrived at Batavia.
See also the MERENBERG (8120).
LES QUATRES FRERES flew the Prussian flag. The 51 men, who departed from Batavia, included two passengers.

LA (BONNE) RESOLUTION flew the Swedish flag. The port of destination in patria and the date of arrival there are unknown. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The (BONNE) RES-OLUTION had sailed on its own account from a French Atlantic port via the Cape to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. From Mauritius the ship sailed on to Batavia.
4458/8148 was the second voyage of this ship, which during the preceding voyage (4400/8087) was called BERLIN.
According to K.A. 4293 Hendrik Holder was master of the EIK EN LINDE.
At the departure from the Cape the HOOP was accompanied by a Dutch man-of-war.

The ELISABETH ET SOPHIE flew the French flag. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The ELISABETH ET SOPHIE had sailed on its own account from Lorient in France (departure: 04-11-1783) via the Cape (05 till 26-04-1784) to Mauritius. There it had officially entered the Company's service. From Mauritius the ship had sailed on to Batavia.

The NEPTHUNE flew the French flag. See LA DAME JEANNE (8111). The NEPTHUNE had sailed on its own account from a French Atlantic port via the Cape to Mauritius, where it had officially entered the Company's service. From Mauritius the ship had sailed on to Batavia.
The 31 people, who departed from Batavia, included two passengers.
After the return to Texel the ship was renamed MERENBERG (4556/8223).
From 25-11-1786 till 18-08-1787 the AFRIKAAN was at Crookhaven in Ireland.
Although the JAN EN CORNELIS sailed for the Chamber Amsterdam, it cast anchor at Rammekens.
4502/8175 was the second voyage of this ship, which during the preceding voyage (4409/8098) was called LES DEUX SOEURS.
On 26-03-1787 the DRAAK lost its masts and pan of the rigging. For that reason the ship called at Mauritius, 12-04 till 22-10-1787.
The date of the PAREL's arrival at the Cape is unknown. There the ship was broken up in 1788. See also the VREDE (8214).
According to K.A. 4304 Sijbrand Berk was master of the VROUWE WIJNANDA LUBERTA.
At the Cape the AVENHORN was wrecked.

third voyage of this ship, which during its first voyage (4400/8087) was called BERLIN.
The VREDE carried the cargo of the homeward-bound PAREL, laid up at the Cape (see 8193).
On 01-06-1788 the JAVA arrived at Simon's Bay. Three and a half months later the ship sailed to the Cape to be repaired.
Sailing from China to the Cape the ADMIRAAL DE SUFFREN was wrecked, in the South China Sea.
